Description: Body sherd of Chian Grand Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior glazed black with lotus flower and elaborate tendril in added red and added white; exterior: painted decoration consisting of horse and rider to right (torso, arms and thigh of rider with white flesh, short chiton with upper part red and bottom black; of horse, red back, red mane and black shoulder with red marks remaining).
Curator's comments: The sherd belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1924,1201.413. Although Lemos does not discuss this specific sherd, she does discuss 1924,1201.413, which she describes as possibly belonging to the Naukratis Painter. The painter and the group are named after a chalice found at Naukratis and the slip on all vessels from this group is a light beige to almost creamy white. Rim patterns are very simple and there is no filling ornament. The depiction of figures, however, is very elaborate. Clothing is rendered highly decorated and naked skin is expertly portrayed.
In pencil on inside '82..' - end obscured.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 278, no. 756, pl. IV)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0733) (phase 2)
